bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to James Carroll, September 30, 1901

div1.p: Reed discusses Carroll's experiments, comments on Springer's involvement, and makes recommendations.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to James Carroll, September 30, 1901

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Sept 30.

div1.p:
Yours
of Septr 24th has been
received- I sympathize
with you fully over for the
unhappy miscarriage
of your experiment with
the filtrate- Of course,
Springer imagined
that he knew everything
about the apparatus
and that his mechanical
talents could not lead
him astray- I am now
very sorry that you took
him, as I suppose that he
has really been of
no use to you. His
disclosure of your work
to Guiteras was rep-
rehensible in the ex-
treme and I cannot
understand such
conduct at all- If
you think it best to leave
Springer in Cuba for
his misconduct, let
me know, & I will see that he stays-
I got Col. Forwood to wire Col. Brown
to get your filters & valve attachment
for vacuum pump & also wrote to Eriner &
Armand to send at once by mail
the articles- You may get dupli-
cates of these articles -- but that will
make no difference- They are addressed
in care of chief surgeon, Havana-
Stay as long as if is nec-
essary to make this ex-
periment- I sincerely
hope that you can get here
by Novr 1st, as the Army
School will then begin, &
I couldn't get along without
you- Will do the best we
can with the Columbian
class- If you have no
success by Nov Octr 25th,
You had better start back
at that time, & we can
try again next year.
div1.closer:
In haste, & with best
wishes, sincerely yours, Walter Reed.
